Award.AwardTitle: Coastal SEES Collaborative Research: Changes in actual and perceived coastal flood risks due to river management strategies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The most populated cities in the world are located on deltaic coastal floodplains because of their rich fertile soils and plentiful natural resources. River deltas are disappearing at increasing rates due to human-caused changes to sediment supply and river flow, gradual sinking of land, and rising sea level, threatening the sustainability of human settlements on coastal river deltas. River management projects, including those designed to promote navigation and reduce flooding, have in some cases accelerated land loss and increased the threat of hurricane flooding. This project will explore the relationships among human river management, sediment supply, wetland building capacity, coastal flood risk, and human perception of flood risk. Testing the connections between river management, wetland loss, and flood risks will improve prediction of future coastal system states and produce guidelines for how to sustainably manage sediment supply and maintain human settlement in coastal areas. Other broader impact activities will include graduate and undergraduate education, application to public policy, and public and K-12 outreach. These are all unified through the general recognition in Louisiana (like many other deltaic coasts) that the science of deltaic restoration has strong and direct impacts on local welfare and economies. This project is supported as part of the National Science Foundation's Coastal Science, Engineering, and Education for Sustainability program - Coastal SEES.

This project will explore the co-evolution of deltaic landscapes and human system response by focusing on changes in coastal flood risks due to human manipulations of sediment delivery. Three experimental coastal basins in the central Mississippi River Deltaic Plain with distinct histories of sediment delivery by rivers and wetland loss responses will be investigated. An interdisciplinary team of researchers will combine field studies and modeling approaches to characterize: 1) feedbacks between human river management strategies that reduce sediment delivery and corresponding landscape degradation and 2) causal links between landscape degradation resulting from reduced sediment delivery, increased flood risks from hurricane storm surges, and human responses to perceived flood risks. The team will explore historical and future outcomes of river management strategies, including reorganization of human settlement in coastal areas using computer simulations incorporating how sediment supply builds land and human response to flood risks. Testing these system interactions in a modeling framework will produce foundational knowledge that can inform management decisions and promote sustainable human settlements on deltaic landscapes.

Performance_Institution.Name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

POR.DRECONTENT:
Close examination of a map of coastal Louisiana from the 19th century versus a recent 21st century map makes clear the technological advancements that have led to better descriptions of our Earth?s surface at the coastal land margin and beyond. That almost apples to oranges distinction is impressively dramatic, but problematic when wanting to directly compare how water flooded over the surface then as opposed to now, let alone to consider what may happen in the future. The main pursuit of this generous NSF grant was a description of coastal Louisiana for the 50-year intervals spanning 1850 to present day. The essential outcome is landscape ecosystem models that are defined by a technique that allows for direct comparisons of the digital representations of surface elevations, including coastal land loss over eras. The process includes definition of the general vegetative species covering the land and serves as a basis for comparative storm surge simulations. The basic research that resulted in this capability produced a stream of outcomes that will extend well beyond the life of the project.

The landscape ecosystem models and hurricane storm surge simulation results were produced for 1850, 1890, 1930, 1970, 1990, and 2010. And what was gleaned from those results enabled the projection of the coast of Louisiana for 2030, 2050, 2070, 2090 and 2110 along with how it might respond to hurricane storm surge in the future. This basic research has the very practical outcome of helping to identify what management processes impacted coastal Louisiana historically and what processes may dominate into the future.  Results indicate that past changes in the Louisiana coastal landscape and storm surge were a consequence of local land and river management decisions while future changes are dominated by relative (subsidence and eustatic) sea level rise.

Intellectual merit project outcomes begin with our direct and important contribution to the larger team publication in Sustainability Science (http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11625-016-0374-4) and our subsequent two Coastal Engineering publications (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.coastaleng.2018.03.006 and https://doi.org/10.1016/j.coastaleng.2019.04.010). Together these three articles describe the natural science and technological developments for how to describe the coastal land margin of Louisiana from 1850 into the future within the context of hurricane storm surge assessments. Those assessments are well described in the context of historical and future storm surge flooding in two Climatic Change journal articles (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-019-02575-7 and https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-019-02636-x). From this basic research intellectual pursuits are possible that include more complete bio-geo-physical and socio-economic model advancements and analyses for present and future conditions.

Broader impact project outcomes begin with the PhD student who worked solely on this project, wrote and successfully defended a dissertation, graduated and is now working for a major coastal engineering firm.  The basic research has direct contributions of science to practical research that is being pursued to help Louisiana build resilience to present and future flooding. Research conducted under this project serves the RESTORE Act Louisiana Center of Excellence grant to the PI and colleagues for ?Coupling Hydrologic, Tide and Surge Processes to Enhance Flood Risk Assessments for the Louisiana Coastal Master Plan.? The National Academies of Science and Robert Woods Johnson program has provided a grant to LSU to pursue ?Inland from the Coast: A multi-scalar approach to regional climate change responses,? on which the PI is a key personnel. More proposals are being developed, not the least of which is a NSF Science and Technology Center proposal that relies heavily on the overall findings of this and the larger team NSF Coastal SEES grant.

The State of Louisiana plans to spend $1billion every year on coastal protection and restoration for the next 50 years. Using wetland vegetation to mitigate hurricane impacts has been advocated in Louisiana and beyond. There is a strong potential that the new understanding, methodology and numerical models developed in the project will greatly benefit the US Army Corps of Engineers, and the state and local planners and designers to build a sustainable deltaic coast by demonstrating the change in storm surge and flood risk to coastal communities 1850-2110. By providing planners and policymakers approximate historic flood costs for individual coastal communities across Louisiana incentivizes proactive approaches to flood risk reduction by revealing the relatively recent upward trend in risk reduction costs that will only be exacerbated in coming decades. Clearly the broader impacts of this NSF Coastal SEES grant will be sustained.
